title: DDT as a Persistent Organic Pollutant

content.question: Which of the following best describes why <math alttext="D D T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>D</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is classified as a persistent organic pollutant?

choices.label: <math alttext="D D T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>D</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is very stable, and as much as 50% of the original concentration can remain in the soil 15 years after the initial application.

<math alttext="D D T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>D</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> can be used to control diseases, such as malaria and typhus, that are spread by insects.

<math alttext="D D T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>D</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is detected in food worldwide and the general human population is most commonly exposed to the toxin through food.

<math alttext="D D T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>D</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> has both short-term acute and long-term chronic health effects in both humans and wildlife.
